awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: A Reliable and Efficient New Method for Satellite Attitude Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project offers significant changes to the conventional concept of spacecraft orientation control by providing increased agility, along with reduced mass, volume, and cost. These advantages open doors to new scientific and commercial opportunities.  The project addresses the demanding needs of future space observatories and commercial spacecraft that require high agility systems, currently unachievable with existing attitude control solutions. Moreover, this system, as a more affordable 3-axis control option, is set to increase access to space for lower-budget missions, making space exploration more accessible than ever before. The systems application is envisioned to enable advances in sectors such as satellite-to-satellite communications, adding momentum to global digital connectivity initiatives. 

This STTR Phase I project seeks to develop a Multifunctional Structures for Attitude Control (MSAC) system and increase its efficiency and reliability, pushing it towards achieving readiness for flight demonstration. The project addresses the existing challenge of the system's fatigue strength and its compatibility with the harsh space environment, factors crucial for its commercial success and durability in its intended application. This project's aim is to design a flight-capable system, drawing on the insights from lab-scale tests and prototypes.  It also seeks to simultaneously improve the system's mechanical and electrical design to elevate efficiency and reliability standards. Through this research method, the team anticipates a better understanding and eventual mitigation of potential failure modes, paving the way for the realization of a robust, space-ready prototype. The anticipated technical results from this endeavor have the potential to revolutionize the spacecraft attitude control market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: Advancing MSAC

Overview

Multifunctional Structures for Attitude Control (MSAC) represents an innovative approach to reorienting (pointing) satellites and spacecraft. This concept uses solar panels not only for power generation but also for reorientation, vibrating them in small circular patterns for control. Additionally, MSAC provides active jitter cancellation, similar to noise-canceling headphones, to reduce mechanical noise on satellites, which provides enhanced stability for sensitive payloads, such as optics/cameras.

This project focused on advancing the MSAC system's development for CubeSats and SmallSats, with emphasis on improving its maturity and reliability for operation in space. During Phase 1, mathematical models were developed to create fast-response actuators that are suitable for space and have terrestrial applications, such as stabilizing sensitive equipment. Several material and actuation strategies were evaluated, optimized for CubeSats, and have undergone preliminary endurance testing.

Intellectual Merit

Key achievements in Phase 1 include:

  • Enhanced Mechanical Design: Advanced mathematical models and simulations were used to develop a more accurate understanding of the actuator structures needed for satellites of different sizes, enabling precise control movements for pointing.
  • Actuator Evaluation: Various actuators, including piezoelectric stacks and Lorentz force actuators, were assessed for their adaptability to different satellite sizes and applications. The most effective were optimized for CubeSats.
  • Improved Power Efficiency: The MSAC system's power consumption was reduced by half through redesigning drive electronics and control architecture, critical for extending the operational life of small satellites with limited power.
  • Reliability Testing: Extensive testing confirmed the system's durability and operational lifespan, with accelerated life testing demonstrating that MSAC meets long-term mission requirements.

Broader Impacts

The project's advancements benefit both the satellite industry and society:

  • Commercial Viability: The MSAC system's adaptability to various satellite buses, such as Samara Aerospace's Hummingbird bus, has attracted significant commercial interest, with potential customers anticipating over 110 satellites using Samara's MSAC system in the next five years.
  • Educational Opportunities: The innovative nature of the project provides valuable learning experiences for students and researchers in aerospace engineering, inspiring future advancements in small satellite technology.
  • Advancement of Space Technology: By enabling enhanced maneuverability and control, MSAC supports more complex satellite missions, including Earth observation, scientific research, and communication services.

Conclusion

This project has successfully advanced the MSAC system toward flight readiness, demonstrating its potential to improve the maneuverability and efficiency of CubeSats and SmallSats. These achievements lay a strong foundation for future development and deployment, contributing to advancements in small satellite technologies and broadening access to space-based applications.


Last Modified: 11/12/2024
Modified by: Fnu Vedant
